articles.title: Second Barbary macaque born at safari park
articles.description: Mother Eadie gave birth to Harper at Blair Drummond Safari Park near Stirling in June.
articles.content:
A second Barbary macaque has been born at a Scottish safari park, its thrilled staff have announced.

The infant was born to mother Eadie last month and has been named Harper by its keepers at Blair D... [887 symbols]
articles.summary: A second Barbary macaque has been born at Blair Drummond Safari Park near Stirling, a Scottish safari park. The infant was born to mother Eadie last month and named Harper by its keepers. This follows the birth of Hayley in May. The park staff praised Eade for her natural-first-time motherhood and said Harper is thriving under her protection. Barbary macaques are native to North Africa and Gibraltar, with only around 8,000 left in the wild.

articles.title: US Bird Flu Outbreak Shows ‘Sustained’ Spread Within Mammals, Study Says
articles.description: Scientists issued a warning Thursday over the spread of bird flu (H5N1) between mammals as the virus appears to adapt.
articles.content:
Scientists issued a warning Thursday over the spread of bird flu (H5N1) between mammals as the virus appears to adapt.

The spillover of bird flu from domesticated and wild birds to other mammals has ... [1657 symbols]
articles.summary: Scientists have warned about the spread of bird flu (H5N1) between mammals, suggesting that the virus appears to adapt and may lead to adaptation to mammals and potential efficient transmission into humans. This has been documented globally since at least January 2022, with scientists now concerned about this potential spread in humans. The study author, Diego Diel, did not identify any core mutations in the genome sequence of the disease, suggesting it may be adapting to different mammal hosts. Eleven human cases of birdflu have been reported in the U.S. since April 2022, only five confirmed as H5N 1.

articles.title: NASA telescope discovers Jupiter-like exoplanet that takes more than 100 years to orbit its star
articles.description: The Webb Space Telescope found a gas giant similar to Jupiter, but six times as massive, orbiting the star Epsilon Indi A. It takes this planet more than a century to complete an orbit.
articles.content: • The Webb Space Telescope spotted a gas giant roughly the same diameter as Jupiter, but with six times the mass, orbiting a neighboring star, Epsilon Indi A. It might take this planet as long as 250 ... [2990 symbols]
articles.summary: The Webb Space Telescope has discovered a Jupiter-like exoplanet, which takes over 100 years to orbit its star, Epsilon Indi A, which is 3.5 billion years old and 1 billion years younger than our own solar system. The planet, roughly the same diameter as Jupiter, has six times the mass and its atmosphere is rich in hydrogen like Jupiter’s. It takes up to 250 years to complete an orbit around its star and is 15 times farther from its star than Earth is to the sun. The discovery was made by an international team led by Max Planck Institute for Astronomy's Elisabeth Matthews in Germany. The Webb telescope, set to be launched in 2021, is the biggest and most powerful astronomical observatory ever placed in space.

articles.title: China Initiative a ‘significant push factor’ for Chinese scientists’ US exodus
articles.description: The number of ethnic Chinese scientists leaving the US rose rapidly after the launch of the China Initiative, study finds.
articles.content: Meanwhile, the percentage of those leaving the US who chose to relocate to mainland China and Hong Kong increased from 48 per cent in 2010 to 67 per cent in 2021, according to the findings published o... [3422 symbols]

entities.data: the Stanford Centre on China’s Economy and Institutions

articles.summary: A study by researchers from Stanford University has found that a 75% increase in Chinese scientists leaving the US since the implementation of the "China Initiative", a US government probe which attempted to combat economic espionage but instead prosecuted academics. The number of Chinese scientists choosing to relocate to mainland China and Hong Kong has also increased from 48% in 2010 to 67% in 2021. While most China-born, US-based scientists intend to stay in the US, departures have grown steadily, from 900 to 2,621 in 2021, according to the study. The study used the database Microsoft Academic Graph to identify 19,955 scientists of Chinese descent who later left for other countries, including China. It also found that 42% were afraid of conducting research in the United States, while 65% worried about collaborations with China.

articles.title: Cozy luxury in Vermont, events for meteor shower, and a sleek travel laptop cover
articles.description: Travel news you can use.
articles.content: Soak in an outdoor hot tub, slip into a cold plunge pool, and relax in a cedar sauna at a new property in the heart of Vermont’s Green Mountains. AWOL Stowe opens next week on Mountain Road in Stowe —... [3441 symbols]
articles.summary: A new boutique property, AWOL Stowe, Vermont, has opened next week and offers understated luxury in a natural setting. The new property, one of Lark Hotels' AWOL-brand properties, features 35 guest rooms and suites, an outdoor Nordic spa, and a restaurant and four-seat bar. The guest-only restaurant serves craft cocktails and light bites such as charcuterie boards and deviled eggs with trout roe. The Lake House on Canandaigua in upstate New York offers a special package during the annual Perseid meteor shower, which includes a floating sound bath on Cancanigua Lake, tarot card readings, and an Art-strological Painting Class. The Matador Laptop Base Layer offers a lightweight (5.3 ounces), waterproof (IPX6), and adjustable (adjustment) laptop sleeve.

articles.title: Essay
articles.description: The greenhouse gas warms the planet far more than carbon dioxide but dissipates more quickly. There are many promising ways to cut emissions.
articles.content: If greenhouse gases were prizefighters, methane would be a heavyweight—a powerful puncher that tires quickly. Pound for pound, it is 90 times stronger than carbon dioxide (CO ) at warming the Earth. B... [688 symbols]
articles.summary: Methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, is 90 times stronger than carbon dioxide (CO), but it is also shorter lived than CO and leaves the air naturally after only a decade. If we could eliminate all methane emissions from human activities, including agriculture, waste, and fossil fuels, the level of methane in Earth’s atmosphere would fall to preindustrial levels within a decade or two, reducing global warming by 0.5 of a degree Celsius. This would significantly aid efforts to keep increased global warming from all gases below 1.5 or 2 degrees.

articles.title: Hens blush when excited or scared, study finds
articles.description: Blushing was once thought to be the “most peculiar and most human of all expressions,” as Charles Darwin put it, but a new study has found that hens share this peculiarity and can also express their fear or excitement in this way.
articles.content: Blushing was once thought to be the “most peculiar and most human of all expressions,” as Charles Darwin put it, but a new study has found that hens share this peculiarity and can also express their f... [3449 symbols]

entities.data: the National Institute of Agricultural Research

articles.summary: A study by researchers from the National Institute of Agricultural Research (NIR) and the University of Tours has found that hens can also express their fear or excitement through their subtle expressions. The study, which included researchers from several French institutes and several French institutions, found that chickens fluffed their head feathers when they were content and calm, and that blushing for a few seconds indicated a reaction to excitement and fearful situations. The researchers also found that while these expressions are not directly comparable to human emotions, they also blush within seconds during strong emotions. The findings were published in the journal Plos One.

articles.title: NASA telescope spots a super Jupiter that takes more than a century to go around its star
articles.description: Astronomers have directly observed a super Jupiter around a nearby star NASA telescope spots a super Jupiter that takes more than a century to go around
articles.content:
NASA telescope spots a super Jupiter that takes more than a century to go around its starBy MARCIA DUNNAP Aerospace WriterThe Associated PressCAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) — A super ... [2737 symbols]
articles.summary: A super Jupiter has been spotted around a neighboring star by the NASA's Webb Space Telescope, taking over a century to complete its orbit. The planet is roughly the same diameter as Jupiter, but with six times its mass and its atmosphere is rich in hydrogen like Jupiter's. It takes over 100 years to complete this orbit, and is 15 times the distance from its star than Earth is to the sun. The observations were collected by an international team led by the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy’s Elisabeth Matthews in Germany. The star is so close and bright to our own solar system that it can be seen with the naked eye in the Southern Hemisphere. The discovery could help scientists understand how planets like Jupiter evolve over giga-year timescales.

articles.title: The Moon’s Most Shadowy Places Can’t Hide From NASA’s New Camera
articles.description: ShadowCam, a NASA instrument aboard a South Korean spacecraft, is taking pictures of the moon where the sun doesn’t shine.
articles.content:
When a NASA spacecraft passes over Shackleton Crater on the moon and peers in, it sees this: a sea of blackness and nothing more.































































This 13... [2928 symbols]
articles.summary: NASA's new camera, ShadowCam, has enabled NASA to take pictures of the most shadowed craters on the moon, Shackleton Crater, where the sun never shines. The new instrument was provided for Danuri, a South Korean orbiter that arrived at the moon in December. Since 2009, almost all of the moon's surface has been photographed in detail by Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter, but its camera is not sensitive enough to see anything in these permanently shadowed Craters. While the new instrument takes superlong exposures, increasing sensitivity by a factor of about 200, scientists have found that the shadowed areas are not pitch-black. The images reveal white spots on the surface, but so far no ice has been found.

articles.title: Secret garden belongs to sexually depraved Roman Emperor Caligula
articles.description: The very place where a delegation of Alexandria's Jews pleaded with Caligula for relief has been discovered on the banks of Rome's Tiber River during excavations for a new underpass.
articles.content:
The sumptuous terrace where ancient Rome's most-depraved emperor snubbed his people as they pleaded for help has been unearthed in the path of a new underpass.

Despite reigning for just four years, C... [7228 symbols]
articles.summary: The secret garden where Rome's most depraved Roman Emperor Caligula snubbed his Jewish population during his reign, Caligul, has been discovered during excavations for a new underpass. The site, which dates back to when Caligulas snubled his people as they pleaded for help from him, was found in a wall of brick and travertine marble, with foundations of a colonnaded portico behind. Daniela Porro, special superintendent of Rome, directed the excavation and confirmed that this was where the fateful meeting occurred. The discovery also includes a large open area thought to be the former Horti of Agrippina, named for Caligur's mother, which was discovered during the excavations. The first antisemitic pogrom during his rule in Alexandria, Egypt, occurred during a time of tension between the city's Jewish and Greek populations due to their monotheistic faith.

articles.title: Italian archaeologists make stunning underwater discovery
articles.description: The discovery includes "thousands of marble slabs" in "hundreds of different shapes" found in a submerged ancient city.
articles.content:
Researchers studying an underwater city in Italy say they have found an ancient mosaic floor that was once the base of a Roman villa, a discovery that the local mayor called "stupendous."

The discove... [2014 symbols]
articles.summary: Researchers from the Campi Flegrei Archaeological Park in Italy have discovered an ancient mosaic floor that was once the base of a Roman villa. The discovery was made in Bay Sommersa, a marine-protected area and UNESCO World Heritage Site off the northern coast of the Gulf of Naples. The area, once the Roman city of Baia, has been submerged over the centuries due to volcanic activity. The marble floor is made of second-hand marble that was previously used to decorate other floors or walls. Once recovered, researchers are working to extract the marble pieces from the site and clean them in freshwater tanks to recreate the former mosaic.

articles.summary: There have been two confirmed great white shark sightings off the coast of Maine this week, according to the Atlantic White Shark Conservancy's Sharktivity app. These sightings follow sightings reported off the South Shore and North Shore of Massachusetts a week ago. The app allows users to filter shark sightings as recent as 48 hours or over the last 30 days, or between a custom date range. The last shark attack in Massachusetts was in 2020. John Chisholm, adjunct scientist at New England Aquarium, warned beachgoers to be aware of the growing numbers of seals and sharks.

articles.title: Eagle lands on Arizona police car seeking help in the heat. Watch the video
articles.description: An eagle landed on an Arizona police car seeking relief from the intense summer heat. See how the officer helped the bird in distress.
articles.content:
Eagle lands on Arizona police car seeking help in the heat. Watch the video

Arizona's summer heat is brutal, even for the state's native wildlife.

A sergeant with the Mohave County Sheriff's Office ... [1857 symbols]
articles.summary: A sergeant with the Mohave County Sheriff's Office noticed a bird in distress under his patrol vehicle while working an off-duty road construction assignment. He and a deputy were able to put the bird in the back seat of the patrol vehicle to cool down. The Arizona Raptor Center picked up the bird, which was a young eagle separated from its parents. Officials estimated that the eagle probably wouldn't have survived if not for Sergeant Giralde's actions. The center's recommendations for helping injured birds in Arizona include bringing the animal to Liberty Wildlife at 2600 E. Elwood St. in Phoenix, keeping it in a warm, dark, quiet environment, and not using an eyedropper to give the bird water.

articles.description: Last one to the finish line is a miserable slug.
articles.content: For the next few weeks, Paris will be home to many of the world’s impressive athletes, including some of the fastest human beings on the planet. Among the competitors gathering for the Olympic Games a... [4302 symbols]
articles.summary: The World Snail Racing Championships, held in Congham, England, have attracted athletes from around the world, including runners who can run a marathon in under two hours, a mile in under four minutes and 100 meters in less than 10 seconds. The world record time for completing the 13.5 inch course is 2 minutes flat, which would take snails more than six days to travel a mile. Snail racing is a form of locomotion that requires 12 times as much energy as running. Nicholas Dickinson, who organizes the race with his fellow snail master Ian Haynes, said the glacial pace of the gastropods is the result of Olympic-level exertion. The winning snail, Jeff, was crowned the new world champion.

articles.summary: Yorkshire Wildlife Park, a South Yorkshire animal park, has announced the death of Amur tiger Sayan, a 14-year-old female tiger who died due to an age-related illness. The park confirmed that Sayan had been suffering from a progressive age related illness and despite efforts by rangers and her veterinary team, her health continued to worsen. Staff made the "difficult decision" to put Sayan to sleep.

articles.title: Irish museum solves mystery of bronze age axe heads delivered in porridge box
articles.description: Artefacts sent by farmer, who made the ‘absolutely mad’ discovery while cutting silage
articles.content: When the national museum of Ireland received two 4,000-year-old axe heads, “thoughtfully” wrapped in foam inside a porridge box, from an anonymous source last month, it put out an appeal. The objects ... [2730 symbols]
articles.summary: The national museum of Ireland received two 4,000-year-old bronze age axe heads from an anonymous source last month, which were wrapped in foam inside a porridge box. The museum appealed for more information about the find but was unable to confirm its location. Farmer Thomas Dunne, from County Westmeath, identified as the mysterious sender, who made the discovery while using a metal detector on his land. It is illegal in Ireland to search for archaeological objects without permission and could result in up to three months in prison or a fine of up to €63,486. Researchers from the national museum have now visited the site to log it in an effort to find more information on the people who lived there 4,00 years ago.

articles.title: Allotment owners threatened with eviction unless they remove beehives
articles.description: Allotment owners Helen Randsome and Zoe Shelley have been threatened with eviction unless they remove their beehives - by a council that claims to want to encourage wildlife.
articles.content:
Two allotment owners have been threatened with eviction unless they remove their beehives - by a council that claims to want to encourage wildlife.

Helen Ransome and Zoe Shelley could be stung for th... [5937 symbols]
articles.summary: Two Southampton allotment owners, Helen Ransome and Zoe Shelley, have been threatened with eviction unless they remove their beehives by the Labour-run city council, which claims to want to encourage wildlife. The pair had re-introduced 200,000 pollinators to the area without permission and have warned that it would be a 'travesty' for the city and its plants if threats to re-home their beloved bees are carried out. The row started after the retirement of a plot owner who kept bees, prompting the return of bees to the site in April. Despite receiving no complaints, the council has ordered them to remove the hives or face eviction from the site after being spotted during a routine inspection. The council, known for encouraging wildflower areas, has been accused of hypocrisy by the owners who are seeking retrospective permission.

articles.title: Putin's forces humiliated in massive assault that ended in losses
articles.description: The Russian leader ordered his troops to capture more territory in the Donetsk region, but the push near Kurakhove resulted in mass death and destruction.
articles.content:
Footage captured the moment Vladimir Putin's forces were left humiliated when one of his biggest recent assaults of his war on Ukraine ended in substantial losses.

The Russian leader had ordered his ... [3962 symbols]
articles.summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's forces were humiliated in a major assault near Kurakhove, eastern Ukraine, which resulted in significant losses. The failed assault led to the deaths of 40 invaders and injuries of 37 more. Ukraine's paratroopers destroyed six Russian tanks and seven advancing armoured combat vehicles, and the Russian attack group was targeted by anti-tank gunners. The Russian army launched the assault from several directions and involved 57 armoured vehicles, 11 tanks, 12 motorcycles, and 200 assault vehicles. The Ukrainian brigade had spotted the Russian equipment in advance and attacked them through relentless artillery fire. The British Army head General Sir Roly Walker warned that if Russia continues its attacks on Ukraine, it will take five years for its forces to achieve a minimum goal of fully capturing just four regions at a loss of up to 1.8 million soldiers.

The project promises to boost Chicago as a leader in the nascent quantum computing field, while revitalizing the city’s Southeast Side, which has struggled ...
articles.content: In what could be a transformational development for Chicago, California-based tech company PsiQuantum is investing billions in the long dormant South Works site in a quest to build the world’s first c... [4925 symbols]
articles.summary: California-based tech company PsiQuantum is investing billions in the long dormant South Works site in Chicago to develop the world's first commercially viable quantum computer. The project is expected to boost the city as a leader in the quantum computing field and revitalize the Southeast Side, which has been struggling economically since U.S. Steel closed its plant more than 30 years ago. PSIQuantum, which was founded in 2015, aims to build and deploy the world’s first useful, large-scale quantum computer, which could bring $20 billion in economic impact, thousands of jobs and elevated technological standing to the city over the next decade. The company will anchor the new Illinois Quantum and Microelectronics Park at the site.

articles.title: Carbon footprint of Olympic visitor is equivalent to eating 31 burgers

articles.content:
If you're attending the Olympic Games in Paris in the next couple of weeks, be warned that your carbon footprint will soar.

Each Olympic visitor is accountable for 100kg of CO2 emissions, a scientist... [4028 symbols]
articles.summary: A scientist from Polytechnique Montréal in Canada, Dr Anne de Bortoli, has warned that carbon emissions at the Paris 2024 Olympics will increase due to transport, food, energy generation, construction, transport, and construction. The maximum carbon budget for Paris 2024 has been set at 1.58 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent (Mt CO2 eq). This is an ambitious target for Olympic organisers, especially considering the Tokyo 2020 Games generated almost 2 Mt CO2. The exact carbon footprint of Paris 2024 will be known after the games, but it is estimated to be 1.6 MtCO2 eq for 13 to 16 million visitors, or around 100 to 125 kg CO2 emissions per person. De Bortol urges measures to limit global warming and comply with the Paris Agreement.

articles.title: 50-year-old gorilla’s motherly role at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo reveals amazing adaptability
articles.description: An aged gorilla named Freddy at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo has been nursing a youngster, six-month-old Jameela, after the zoo took in for foster care, revealing much about adaptability and family functions.
articles.content:
CLEVELAND – Watching Fredrika tend to her young daughter, Jameela, in the western lowland gorilla group at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo is like observing any other mother doting on her child.

But Fre... [4260 symbols]
articles.summary: The 50-year-old gorilla, Fredrika, known as Freddy, is a mother to Jameela, a young gorilla at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo, who was born prematurely in January and came to the zoo when her mother did not show proper maternal care. Despite her older age, Freddy, who is now nursing Jameel, proved remarkably adaptable to her role as a mother. The experience has revealed the adaptability of gorillas and how they function as a family group. The zoo is the first zoo in the world to foster a baby gorilla from the start, with Freddy taking over raising another gorilla, Kayembe, after his birth mother failed to properly care for him following his birth. An analysis of Freddy's milk found it contained proper levels of calories and nutrients.

articles.description: The United Nations’ cultural agency has decided against putting the Buddhist pilgrimage...
articles.content: FILE- Sayamongkhoun Alexandera, right, a Buddhist monk from France, prays in front of the birthplace of Lord Buddha, in Lumbini, about 290 kilometers (175 miles) southwest of Katmandu, Nepal, Nov. 30,... [2608 symbols]
articles.summary: The United Nations' cultural agency, the World Heritage Committee, has decided not to place Lumbini, Buddha's birthplace in Nepal, on its endangered list. Instead, it gave Nepal more time to restore the gardens and temple that are falling into disrepair. UNESCO had recommended placing it on the agency's list of sites in danger due to the deterioration of key features. The move was meant to garner international support for conservation efforts rather than punishment. However, it can lead to the site being dropped from UNESCO's prestigious list of heritage sites. The World Heritage committee noted Nepal's efforts to preserve the site and gave Nepal until 2025 to submit a new report on the state of conservation.

articles.summary: Orezone Gold Corporation (TSX: ORE, OTCQX: ORZCF) is set to begin a 30,000 Metre Discovery Focused Drill Program at its flagship Bomboré Gold Mine in Burkina Faso. The Company aims to test the size and scale of the bomboré mineralized system, which has been reserve defined over a 14km strike length. The current stated gold resource is 4.5Moz Measured and Indicated, and 0.6Moz Inferred. Patrick Downey, President & CEO of Orezone, expressed excitement over the project's potential transformation and potential life-of-mine growth. The initial 30,00m first pass drill program will consist of 5,000m of drilling centered on the Maga Zone, with drilling progressing towards the southern half of the mining lease. Potential exploration also includes exploration of the P17 Trend, which could potentially sequence higher-grade ounces into the front end of the mine plan and expand gold production.

articles.title: US Bird Flu Outbreak Seeing 'Sustained' Spread Between Mammals, Study Warns
articles.description: A new study has revealed a concerning development in the U.S. bird flu outbreak, with the virus now spreading between mammals.
articles.content:
Bird flu has made a concerning leap from birds to dairy cattle across multiple U.S. states, marking the onset of mammal-to-mammal transmission.

This development has seen the virus spreading between c... [2823 symbols]

entities.data: the Ohio Animal Disease and Diagnostic Laboratory

articles.summary: Bird flu has spread from birds to dairy cattle across multiple U.S. states, marking the onset of mammal-to-mammal transmission. This has led to the virus spreading between cows and even jumping to other animals, including cats and a raccoon. So far, 11 human cases have been reported in the U.K., four of which were linked to cattle farms and seven to poultry farms. While whole genome sequencing did not reveal any mutations making bird flu more transmissible to humans, this suggests that the virus may be adapting in mammals. The concern is that potential mutations could lead to human adaptation, spillover into humans, and efficient transmission in humans. The study was funded by the AHDC, the Ohio Animal Disease and Diagnostic Laboratory, the Texas A&M Veterinary Medical Diagnostics Laboratory and the USDA.

The animal was found on his bird feeder, which usually attracts grey squirrels and birds including starlings. The Sussex Wildlife Trust confirmed the animal was a one-in-100,000 genetic occurrence. The animal was found on his bird feeder, which usually attracts grey squirrels and birds including starlings. A Sussex Wildlife Trust spokesperson confirmed the animal was a one-in-100,000 genetic occurrence. Claire Brimacombe, who runs the website White Squirrels of Sussex, has reported about 2,900 sightings of the rare animals and believes the number of squirrels in the country may be higher than some estimates. She believes there is an overrepresentation of sightings in Kent and Sussex, where the alinino gene seems to have been present for many years.

articles.summary: The United Nations' cultural agency, UNESCO, has decided not to place Lumbini, the birthplace of Buddha in Nepal, on its list of heritage sites in danger, but instead gave Nepal more time to restore the gardens and temple that are falling into disrepair. The World Heritage Committee noted Nepal's ongoing efforts to preserve the site and gave Nepal until 2025 to submit a new report on the state of conservation. The decision was made at its annual meeting, with Lebanon arguing against the extension. UNESCO experts had recommended placing it on the endangered list due to the deterioration of key features. The site, which includes over 50 properties, is currently attracting over a million visitors a year and includes a Gautam Buddha International Airport.

articles.summary: China has developed a new material that can efficiently extract uranium from seawater for its nuclear energy ambitions. The material consists of “SA-DNA hydrogel microspheres” with organic structures that are about 2mm across and contain numerous micrometre-sized pores. The research group at the Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology (QIBEBT) under the Chinese Academy of Sciences developed a “cost-effective” material that they claim has “exceptional uranium adsorption capability”. The materials were created by combining sodium alginate with functional strands of DNA that recognise and bind to uranium ions. The team's findings were published in the peer-reviewed Chemical Engineering Journal.

articles.title: Study looks at if the French Paradox of a glass of wine a day is actually a myth
articles.description: The French paradox, popularised in the 1990s, claimed red wine helps explain why France hasrelatively low rates of heart disease
articles.content:
Experts have looked into the suggestion a glass of wine a day is good for you, with results not everyone will be happy about.

Studies indicating that it may be beneficial to drink small amounts of al... [2468 symbols]

entities.data: the Canadian Institute for Substance Use Research
the Journal Of Studies On Alcohol and Drugs

articles.summary: A study by Tim Stockwell, of the Canadian Institute for Substance Use Research at the University of Victoria, has found that studies suggesting moderate drinking may be beneficial to small amounts of alcohol are often compared to those who have given up due to health reasons. The researchers compared 107 published studies to their findings, which found that light to moderate drinkers had a 14% lower risk of dying during the study period compared to abstainers. However, higher quality studies that included people relatively young at the start and excluded former and occasional drinkers did not link moderate drinking to a longer life. The study also found that there is no completely ‘safe’ level of drinking and that the previously held position that some level of alcohol was good for the heart has been revised.

articles.content: Photographing an elephant meandering across the African plains may be a safari cornerstone, but glimpsing a “super tusker”—a gargantuan pachyderm hefting ivories that weigh more than 100 pounds apiece... [1841 symbols]
articles.summary: LADY alumni Nicky and Steve Fitzgerald, along with cofounder Steve Mitchell, have created a new safari camp Angama Amboseli, a new contemporary safari lodge in southern Kenya's Amboseled National Park and the 5,700-acre Kimana Sanctuary. The lodge, which opened in 2023, will be sister to the high-end Angama Mara resort in Kenya's Maasai Mara. It is also a hub for wildlife exploration, providing a crucial wildlife corridor and exclusive use of the sanctuary. The partnership with conservation nonprofit Big Life has been instrumental in reducing human-wildlife conflict in the area, with Angama's deal with the Kimana landowners partnership worth $11 million over 25 years (a significant investment currently unmatched by other existing area accommodation). The resort is bringing new attention to the region's star megafauna, as hunting by license is legal in nearby Tanzania and three large-tusked Amboseling-ecosystem elephants were recently trophy-hunted as recently as March.

articles.description: Discovered by the same team that found the Trinidad last year, the Margaret A. Muir has several Wisconsin ties that make it culturally interesting.
articles.content: ALGOMA - Less than a year after finding a long-lost shipwreck considered one of the most significant in Lake Michigan, a team from the Wisconsin Underwater Archeology Association has located another h... [10437 symbols]

entities.data: the National Register of Historic Places

articles.summary: A team from the Wisconsin Underwater Archeology Association has discovered a 131-year-old shipwreck off the Algoma shore in Lake Michigan. The Margaret A. Muir, a 130-foot-long, three-masted schooner built in Manitowoc, was found with high-resolution side-scanning sonar and will be nominated for the National Register of Historic Places. This discovery comes less than a year after the team found another significant shipwreck in the same area. The Muir was built in 1872 and carried mainly grain and other cargoes throughout the Great Lakes until it sank in 1893. The team's findings follow the discovery of the Trinidad, another historic lost shipwreck, which was named to the Wisconsin and National Registers Of Historic Places last year.

The prairie dogs of Yukon are little hometown legends.

They're a reminder in developed suburbia that Oklahoma is still part of the Great Plains. To some, however, they're a pest.

articles.summary: A wildlife researchers have successfully relocated a prairie dog colony in Yukon, Oklahoma, where they captured over three-dozen prairie dogs and relocated them to a site in northwestern Oklahoma. The nearly 18-acre plot, which was recently sold for over $2.1 million, was located within Oklahoma City limits and had recently been for sale. The relocation was led by the Oklahoma Department of Wildlife Conservation and researchers from the University of Louisiana. Kurt Kuklinski, wildlife diversity and research supervisor at the Oklahoma department of Wildlife, said the colony still has far more prairie animals than the 38 captured last week. The current property owner, Nandini LLC, has insisted that non-lethal means should be used to remove the animals. After their capture, samples of blood and tissue were taken for research purposes before being moved to a wildlife management area.

Caiman House, a wildlife research center and lodge on the banks of the Rupununi River, is a wildlife center dedicated to conservation efforts. The lodge's profits are used for village, wildlife, and cultural preservation projects, including a research program to reduce the loss of endemic yellow-spotted river turtles threatened by flooding and human consumption. Visitors can also see the lodge’s black caiman research first-hand, and watch as researchers weigh, measure, sex, tag, and release the endemic species.

articles.summary: The CERN Science Gateway, a family-friendly, admission-free offshoot of the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), will open in fall 2023. The new building was designed by Renzo Piano and features a transparent skywalk between two raised tubular buildings, reminiscent of his Centre Pompidou in Paris. The Gateway includes labs and exhibition spaces for all ages, with works by artists such as Julius von Bismarck, Swiss sculptor Chloé Delarue, and Korean composer Yunchul Kim. The main campus of CERN also houses the Large Hadron Collider, the world's largest particle accelerator.

articles.title: Drinking concentrated fruit juice may cause diabetes in young boys, study warns
articles.description: Daily serving of sugary drinks linked to 34 per cent increase in insulin resistance among boys
articles.content:
Drinking sugary beverages and concentrated fruit juices in childhood and adolescence may raise the risk of diabetes in boys, a new study has found.

The study of about 500 children in Massachusetts, U... [2656 symbols]
articles.summary: A study by the American Heart Association has found that drinking sugary beverages and concentrated fruit juices in childhood and adolescence may increase the risk of diabetes in boys, according to the study. The study, which surveyed 500 children in Massachusetts, found that regular consumption of sugary drinks and fruit juices was linked to a higher risk of developing Type 2 diabetes among boys compared to girls. The findings support evidence of a link between consumption of added sugar and the long-term risk of Type 2 Diabetes in young people. The lead author of the study, Soren Harnois-Leblanc, warned that health professionals should caution young patients and their parents about these drinks when discussing healthy eating habits.

articles.title: Cure for baldness? Naturally occurring sugar  stimulates hair growth
articles.description: If you're anxiously checking your hairline, there is finally good news as scientists have found a potential cure for male pattern baldness.
articles.content:
The fear of going bald is something that weighs on the minds, and scalps, of millions of men around the world.

But if you're anxiously checking your hairline, there is finally good news as scientists... [4163 symbols]
articles.summary: Researchers from the University of Sheffield and COMSATS University Pakistan have discovered that naturally occurring sugar, 2-deoxy-D-ribose (2dDR), can stimulate hair growth in mice. The sugar was found to be equally effective at restoring hair to the balding rodents as commercially available drug minoxidil, also known as Rogaine. The researchers applied the sugar to the skin in a gel, which increased the growth of blood vessels, but found that the hair grew back much faster in the areas around the wound where the gel was applied. The research suggests that using a naturally occurring deoxy ribose sugar to boost the blood supply to the hair follicles could provide a safer, naturally occurring alternative to current treatments.

articles.title: Scientists recreate surprisingly precise Neanderthal recipes and cooking methods
articles.description: Archaeologists used a flint tool to butcher two carrion crows, two collared doves and a wood pigeon, all of which Neanderthals ate
articles.content:
Archaeologists have reconstructed Neanderthal butchering and cooking techniques, enhancing our understanding of the daily life, challenges and dietary practices of these ancient human ancestors.

Whil... [2534 symbols]
articles.summary: Archaeologists have reconstructed Neanderthal butchering and cooking techniques, enhancing our understanding of the daily life, challenges and dietary practices of these ancient human ancestors. The study involved using a flint tool to butcher two carrion crows, two collared doves and a wood pigeon, all of which the Neanderthals ate. The methods were selected based on archaeological evidence. The raw birds were butchered raw, then roasted over hot coals until cooked, then butbutred. The researchers found that using the flint flake required “significant precision and effort” and required careful handling to make precise cuts without injuring one’s fingers. The findings could help archaeologists identify visible signs of Neanderthal food preparation in past records. However, further research is required for larger samples and diverse experimental conditions.

articles.title: Urgent warning to Brits over giant hogweed surge
articles.description: 'Britain's most dangerous plant' is at its scorching peak now, experts have warned, and it's set to leave kids, parents, and pets alike with gruesome burns.
articles.content:
'Britain's most dangerous plant' is at its scorching peak now, experts have warned, and it's set to leave kids, parents, and pets alike with gruesome burns.

The sap of the giant hogweed stops our ski... [3934 symbols]
articles.summary: Experts have warned that the 'Britain's most dangerous plant', the giant hogweed, is at its peak and is set to leave children, parents, and pets with severe burns. The plant's sap prevents our skin from protecting itself against the sun, causing painful blisters if exposed to daylight. It causes no immediate pain, allowing those exposed to continue enjoying the good weather until the first burns appear. With school holidays starting and increased outdoor activity increasing, Callum Sinclair, project manager with the Scottish Invasive Species Intiative, said that the plant is now considered the most dangerous in Britain by its size and size. He encouraged those who see the plant in size to report it to the local authority or landowner.

articles.content:

RYE — Area marine life experts say Tuesday’s whale breach and boat strike off the coast of Rye was the “perfec... [7070 symbols]

articles.summary: Experts have called for caution following a whale's breach and boat strike off the coast of Rye, New England, off the Gulf of Maine, which was captured on camera by a student student and has been shared globally. The whale landed on the boat's engine and caused the vessel to tip upward and roll over, sending two fishermen into the Atlantic. The quick rescue of the fishermen, Ryland Kenney and Greg Paquette, was performed by brothers Wyatt Yager, 19, and Colin Yager from Eliot, Maine, who took the video of the incident. Experts are urging boaters to be aware of the whale's movements as it feeds in the area. Ashley Stokes, director of Seacoast Science Center Marine Mammal Rescue, noted that menhaden, also known as "pogies," are being found in abundance this summer, a fish sought by fishermen as bait for striped bass and by whales as food. The jury is still out on whether the whale that hit the 23-foot boat is the same behemoth that previously seen in Kittery’s Pepperrell Cove and the Piscataqua River is believed to be the same whale.

articles.title: Watch out for sharks: the bizarre history of internet outages
articles.description: In a world where a single point of failure can throw our machines into chaos, everything from sharks to authoritarian governments to old ladies have brought the web to its knees.
articles.content:
Watch out for sharks: the bizarre history of internet outages

On Friday 19 July, 2024, the world woke up to what many have called the worst digital crisis of all time. A botched software update from ... [4650 symbols]
articles.summary: On 19 July, 2024, a software update from cybersecurity giant CrowdStrike caused a global outage, resulting in a global disruption of 8.5 million computers. Airlines cancelled over 46,000 flights in a single day, and the New York Film Forum switched to cash payments as its credit card system went down. The incident was blamed on a misconfigured database, which crashed around one million sites and resulted in a significant loss of business and business. This incident has been seen as a warning to never push updates out on a Friday. Other notable internet outages include a near total internet blackout in Bangladesh following a government shutdown following violent clashes between protesters and police. The most recent internet failure was the Y2K Bug, which predicted a global computer failure in 2000.

articles.summary: The first time the two countries' militaries have entered the Alaska air defence zone at the same time, according to North American Aerospace Defence Command (Norad). The command intercepted two Russian Tu-95 and two Chinese H-6 warplanes operating in the Alaska Air Defence Identification Zone (ADIZ). This was also the first time a Chinese aircraft had flown into the ADIZ, an international airspace that acts as a buffer zone with sovereign territory. US F-16 and F-35 fighter jets and Canadian CF-18s intercepted the Chinese and Russian bombers, which remained in international airspace and did not enter American or Canadian sovereign airspace. The incident comes amid increasing military ties between China and Russia, with General Gregory Guillot warning of China's potential to act in the far north.

articles.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope has captured an image of a planet beyond our solar system, Epsilon Indi Ab, located 12 light-years away. The telescope used a coronagraph to capture the faint light from this far-off planet, which is similar to Jupiter but more massive than any other planet previously imaged. The discovery was published in the science journal Nature. The Webb telescope, a collaboration between NASA, the ESA, and the Canadian Space Agency, is designed to peer into the deep cosmos and reveal new insights about the early universe. It also provides a unique view of ancient objects and planets in our galaxy.

articles.title: That didn't take long! Hottest world temperature record broken AGAIN
articles.description: Just one day after scientists announced Sunday was Earth's hottest day, we already have a new record-holder.

Monday (July 22) is now the planet's warmest day in recorded history, according to ex... [3943 symbols]

articles.summary: The EU's climate change programme has confirmed that Monday (July 22) is the hottest day in recorded history, according to experts from the EU's Climate Change Programme. The average global temperature for Monday was 62.87°F (17.15°C) - 0.1°F hotter than Sunday, which was also the hottest. This makes it likely that three consecutive days of global record breaking heat could occur. The record-breaking temperatures are attributed to unseasonably warm oceans, higher temperatures in Antarctica, the western United States, Canada and eastern Siberia. The European climate service Copernicus (CS3) director, Carlo Buontempo, said these peaks are not isolated and climate is warming due to the increase in greenhouse gases emitted by the fossil fuel industry. He warned that as the climate keeps warming, new records are expected to be broken in the future.

'It's our sea turtle': A look at the history of Kemp's ridley recovery, ongoing threats

articles.summary: The world's most endangered sea turtle, Kemp's ridley, has been successfully managed to nest along a protected beach at Padre Island National Seashore in Texas. The species is found down in Mexico, where it is more common, where thousands of Kemp’s ridley sea turtles emerge simultaneously to nest. However, before the 1990s, there were no similar nesting sites in Texas, with 339 confirmed in Texas during the nesting season. The conservationists use “turtle CSI” and genetic testing to identify the maternity of nests. Despite predictions in 2011 that the species would have rebounded by 2024, the species's nesting numbers continue to fluctuate.

articles.title: Global Study Reveals a Powerful Hidden Way Trees Are Fighting Climate Change
articles.description: Tree bark in the world's forests absorbs the greenhouse gas methane, my colleagues and I have demonstrated for the first time on a global scale – a discovery that could have big implications for tackling climate change.

articles.summary: A global study by ecologists and climate scientists from the University of Birmingham has revealed that tree bark in the world's forests absorbs the greenhouse gas methane. This discovery could have significant implications for tackling climate change. The study compared hundreds of tree stems in forests across the Amazon and Panama, Sweden, and the UK. It found that trees absorb methane from their trunks and branches, providing a long-term store of carbon. This could be used to enhance the removal of methane from the atmosphere, which can occur rapidly if enhanced. The researchers estimate that trees take up between 25 and 50 million tonnes of atmospheric methane each year, most of which is taken up by tropical forests. However, deforestation and reforestation can influence atmospheric methane.

articles.summary: Surfer Kai McKenzie, 23, was attacked by a 3m great white shark at North Shore Beach in Port Macquarie, NSW mid-north coast, and lost his leg. His severed leg was found washed up on the beach and placed on ice. He was rushed to John Hunter Hospital in Newcastle with severe blood loss and underwent a major operation. Despite this, it is unclear whether his leg has been reattached. An off-duty police officer saved Mr McKenzie's life by using his dog's leash as a makeshift tourniquet to stem the loss of blood. Despite these setbacks, Mr McKenzie faces a long recovery road, including six to eight weeks if the limb is not reattatched and at least one year if surgery is successful.

articles.summary: Scientists from the University of Sheffield and COMSATS University in Pakistan have discovered a potential new treatment for hereditary-patterned baldness, the most common cause of hair loss in both men and women. The research involved a sugar sugar that naturally occurs in the body and helps form DNA, the 'deoxyribose' part of deoxyribonucleic acid. Researchers applied this sugar to male mice with testosterone-driven hair loss and found that within weeks their fur began growing back faster than in untreated mice. The gel was found to be equally effective with minoxidil, a topical treatment for hair loss, and could potentially be used to treat alopecia or stimulate hair, lash, and eyebrow regrowth following chemotherapy. However, further research is required to confirm the results.

articles.summary: India and the UK have launched a new technology security initiative, expected to boost economic growth and deepen collaboration on critical technologies. The initiative was announced during the first official visit by the new British foreign minister, David Lammy, as part of his efforts to reset U.K.-India relations. The two countries will work together on crucial technologies, including critical minerals and AI, and will also strengthen cooperation on issues like climate, trade, technology and education. Lammy's visit to India also included discussions about defense and security cooperation and the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Prime Minister Narendra Modi welcomed the initiative and expressed hope for a successful free trade agreement with the two countries.

articles.summary: A rare tooth unearthed by seven-year-old boy, James, has been identified as being a rare find from an ancient mammal. The tooth was found in sand brought for the Natural History Museum's Lyme Regis Fossil Festival in Dorset. It was identified as belonging to a prototomus, a meat-eating animal similar in size to a weasel or mongoose. The museum's Dr Neil Adams described the find as a "very nice find". The find has been donated to the museum and could potentially reveal more about the animal's last days to weeks of its life.

articles.description: Tuataras are one of the world’s oldest surviving species and lived on Earth before the dinosaurs.

Ancient three-eyed reptiles get new home at Chester Zoo

A group of ancient three-eyed reptiles, from a species that dates back before the dinosaurs, have been welcomed at a zoo. The reptiles, called ... [1932 symbols]
articles.summary: Ancient three-eyed reptiles, called tuataras, from a species that dates back before dinosaurs, have been welcomed into Chester Zoo, the only zoo in the UK to host them. The reptiles, which first appeared on Earth over 200 million years ago, are estimated to have about 50,000 left in the wild. The zoo's new habitat will house six animals to recreate their natural habitat for the zoo's conservation breeding programme. The animals' third eye, which senses the intensity of sunlight and regulates body temperature, navigation, and hormone regulation, is not used for sight. Conservationists believe their demise was due to introduced species and a changing climate.

articles.content: Scientists have captured the first ever video of a basking shark struck by a boat just hours after it was tagged off the coast of Ireland, a discovery that raises concerns of collision risks faced by ... [3293 symbols]
articles.summary: Scientists from Oregon State University have captured the first time video of a basking shark being hit by a boat just hours after it was tagged off the coast of Ireland. The discovery raises concerns about collision risks faced by endangered marine animals. The female 7m long basking Shark was tagged with a device similar to a FitBit and a connected camera, which was designed to be released from the animal at a predetermined time. However, when the tag was released seven hours after the strike, researchers found that the shark never resumed feeding or other normal behavior. This is the first direct observation of a ship strike on any marine megafauna that scientists are aware of. The findings suggest the risk of vessel strikes on marine animals and the need for measures to combat this threat.

Studies indicating that it may be beneficial to drink small amounts of alcohol are low quality and ofte... [2438 symbols]

articles.summary: A study by Tim Stockwell, lead researcher at the Canadian Institute for Substance Use Research at the University of Victoria, has found that studies suggesting that moderate drinking may be beneficial for small amounts of alcohol are often compared to those who have given up due to health issues. The researchers compared 107 published studies, which combined their data to show that light to moderate drinkers had a 14% lower risk of dying during the study period compared to abstainers. However, higher quality studies that included people who were relatively young at the start and excluded former and occasional drinkers did not link moderate drinking to a longer life. The study, published in the Journal Of Studies On Alcohol and Drugs, found that lower quality studies with older people and no distinction between former drinkers and lifelong abstainers were found to be linked to greater longevity. The NHS has revised its position that some level of alcohol was good for the heart, stating that the evidence on the protective effect from moderate drinking is less strong than previously thought.

articles.summary: A new method of rearing California condors at the Los Angeles Zoo has resulted in a record-breaking 17 chicks this year, according to the zoo. The new method involves using a surrogate parent to rear the chicks, rather than raising them by hand. The newborn birds will be considered for release into the wild under the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's California Condor Recovery Program. The technique is a modification from a previous method used when more fertilized eggs were available. Despite this success, the species remains at risk from lead poisoning and other toxins.

articles.summary: Scientists have raised concerns about the absorption of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), "forever chemicals" which never fully break down, through human skin. The study, published in the journal Environment International, found that shorter-chain PFAS are absorbed more easily through the skin and into the bloodstream compared to longer-chain compounds. This discovery raises additional concerns about routine exposure to PFAS through products that come into contact with the skin.PFAS have been linked to several types of cancer, infertility, high cholesterol, low birthweights, and negative effects on the liver, thyroid, and immune system. Consumer actions can include seeking out PFAS-free personal care and beauty products, supporting policies that restrict PFAS in consumer goods, and advocating for broader action to protect public health and the environment.

Residents believe a chemical may have been introduced into the water, and the HOA may have introduced it. The water from the pond is used to irrigate a development and residents allege this was introduced to reduce a blue-green algae bloom. The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) has requested a water sample from the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP). The FDEP confirmed it is investigating the matter.

articles.content:
The solar system’s smallest planet may have vast riches beneath its surface, according to a stunning discovery by a NASA spacecraft.

Scientists have determined that Mercury, the closest planet to the... [3531 symbols]
articles.summary: A NASA spacecraft has discovered that Mercury, the solar system's smallest planet, may have a 10-mile thick mantle layer of diamonds beneath its surface. The discovery was made using data from NASA's MESSENGER space probe. The team found that Mercury may once have had a carbon-rich magma ocean, which would have formed when the magma seeped to the surface. However, new data and a reevaluation of mass on the planet’s surface suggests that the mantle is not made of graphite, but precious diamond. The scientists used a large-volume press to replicate conditions below Mercury's crust, with temperatures reaching up to 3,950 degrees Fahrenheit. They believe that diamond could have been formed by two processes: the crystallization of the liquid core of Mercury, which formed 4.5 billion years ago, and slowly crystallized over time.

articles.summary: At least one black bear has been spotted in several southern Illinois counties, Saline, Pope, Williamson and Jackson. While bear sightings in Illinois are rare, there are established populations in Missouri and Wisconsin. The Illinois Department of Natural Resources has advised people to avoid direct encounters with bears and check their property for food sources if one is reported nearby. Bears often investigate bird feeders, grills, garbage cans and dog food, and once they find food, they return to the source.

articles.summary: Linda Kosuda-Bigazzi, a 76-year-old woman from Connecticut, was found dead hours before her sentencing for the murder of her doctor husband, Dr. Pierluigi Bigazzi. She had murdered him with a hammer and stashed his body away for seven months while collecting his University of Connecticut paychecks. Her lawyer, Patrick Tomasiewicz, suggested that her death was not anticipated but may have a hand in her fate. In March, she pleaded guilty to manslaughter and larceny in connection to the slaying. The circumstances of her death are still being investigated.

articles.summary: The first ever direct observation of a ship strike on a marine megafauna, a basking shark, was made just hours after it was caught and tagged by researchers in a proposed Irish marine park. The footage was captured on the device she was tagged with, revealing the vulnerability of this vulnerable species to boat strikes. The researchers suggest that even when the collisions are not directly fatal, they can cause detrimental changes in behavior and longer-term consequences like injuries. They also warn that boat strikes may be more common than previously considered due to their non-lethal effects once the shark's skin heals, which could potentially underestimate the extent of boat strike prevalence. The scientists recommend more protected areas throughout basking sharks' range to allow them safe places to feed and assess the impact on their recovery.

articles.summary: Scientists have found a rare North Atlantic right whale, one of the world's rarest large whale species, off the northwest coast of Ireland for the first time in over a century. Adrian Maguire, an honorary research fellow at the Scottish Association for Marine Science, captured footage of the whale and identified it from its large, crusty white callosities on its skin caused by whale lice, a feature unique only to right whales in the region. The International Union for Conservation of Nature's Red List has changed the status of the North Atlantic Right whale to critically endangered in 2020, and estimates that only 200-250 mature individuals remain. Despite these sightings, scientists believe the sighting provides a "glimmer of hope" for the population.

articles.summary: The Los Angeles Zoo has broken a record for its breeding efforts, with 17 condor chicks born at the zoo, breaking the previous record of 17. The chicks are bred and reared at LA Zoo as part of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's California Condor Recovery Program, which aims to restore the population of the endangered birds. The first egg of the season was laid in January, an early start to the season, and the 17th chick hatched in June. The program aims to release the birds in their native habitat in their natural habitat. The new breeding and rearing techniques were pioneered in 2017 by zoo staff, with no other zoo or California Conder Recovery Program partner having previously attempted this feat. The birds are threatened by habitat loss, pesticide contamination, consumption of micro trash, bird flu, and lead poisoning from eating bullet fragments or shot pellets found in animal carcasses.

articles.summary: China's uncrewed reusable spacecraft, which launches atop a rocket booster and lands at a secretive military airfield, is likely to be testing technology but also be used for manipulating or retrieving satellites, according to experts. The spacecraft was observed releasing an object several kilometres away and returning to within a few hundred metres of it. Marco Langbroek, a lecturer in optical space situational awareness at Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands, said that a reusable spacecraft that can interfere with complex satellite networks could have significant value. China has not disclosed what technologies the spacecraft has tested, nor has been publicly photographed since it began operating. The current flight of the Chinese spaceplane began in December 2023 and its first flight was in September 2020.

articles.summary: U.K.-based international nature conservation charity Fauna & Flora has successfully reintroduced the Siamese crocodiles, which were listed as virtually extinct in the wild in 1992. The charity has been working with an Indigenous population of Chorng people in the Cardamom Mountains of Cambodia to protect the small population of these animals, which are considered sacred by the Indigenous people. The conservationists hope this landmark event heralds good things for the future of the species. Only around 1,000 of these estimated 1,300 Siamesed crocodiles are thought to remain in the free wild, with over 300 of them in Cambodia. Fauna and Flora is also working on breeding more Siamesese crocs through captive breeding and recently released an additional 50 juveniles into the wild from captivity. Despite challenges faced by previous wild populations, conservationists believe that if given the right protection, the species will bounce back.

Greg Paquette and Ryland Kenney were... [2284 symbols]
articles.summary: Two fishermen were thrown overboard when a breaching humpback whale capsized their boat off the New Hampshire coast. The incident was caught on video, with Greg Paquette and Ryland Kenney being thrown overboard. The whale reared up out of the water and hit the back of the boat, causing it to take on water. The fishermen were rescued by a good Samaritan and no injuries were reported. The breaching whale was not injured.

articles.title: Questacon comes to Sydney: Nostalgic Aussies delighted with the news
articles.description: A hugely popular science museum from Canberra is headed to Sydney.
articles.content:
A hugely popular science museum from Canberra is headed to Sydney with an immersive travelling exhibition as part of South Eveleigh's Winter Series.

Visitors to Questacon, The National Science and Te... [2425 symbols]
articles.summary: The popular science museum from Canberra, Questacon, is set to visit Sydney for a three-day travelling exhibition as part of South Eveleigh's Winter Series. The exhibition, Byte-Wise, aims to inspire curiosity and confidence in technology and is part of the National Science and Technology Center in Canberra. The museum will also feature interactive exhibits and puppet shows about technology and science. These activities include a silent cinema and a three day brick work and play zone with larger than life displays and an interactive play area full of Lego. The event is part-of Australian National Science Week, taking place from the 10th - 18th of August.

articles.title: Scientists blame climate change for record heatwaves in 2023
articles.description: In its annual State of the Climate report, the Met Office said 2023 had the hottest June on record, the joint warmest September, and the year as a whole was the second warmest on record for the UK.
articles.content:
The UK's record breaking weather in the past 12 months can be blamed on climate change, the Met Office has revealed.

In its annual State of the Climate report, the forecasting body said 2023 had the ... [3813 symbols]
articles.summary: The UK experienced record-breaking weather in 2023, including the hottest June on record, the joint warmest September on record and the second warmest year on record for the UK. The Met Office's annual State of the Climate report stated that human induced climate change made these records'much more likely to happen'. The report highlighted that between 1961 and 1990 only London and Hampshire recorded six days or more with temperatures at 28°C or above, which is considered 'hot' weather. The number of 'pleasant' days (daily maximum 20°C) has increased by 41% for the most recent decade (2014-2023), while the number of warm days (25°C), 'hot', days (28°C%), and'very hot' days have more than doubled over the same period. The report also highlighted an increase in the number number of exceptional rainfall days in the past decade.

articles.title: NASA's ICON mission ends with critical breakthroughs on Earth, space weather
articles.description: Nearly five years after it launched, NASA's Ionospheric Connection Explorer -- or ICON -- mission has officially come to an end, the space agency announced Wednesday.
articles.content: NASA's ICON, shown in this artist’s concept, studied the dynamic zone high in the atmosphere where terrestrial weather from below meets space weather above. On Wednesday, NASA announced the mission's ... [2747 symbols]
articles.summary: NASA's ICON mission, which launched in October 2019 and completed its primary mission two years later, has officially ended. The mission was launched to study the dynamic zone high in the atmosphere where terrestrial weather from below meets space weather above. It provided critical insights on how space weather affects Earth's weather and its impact on satellites and radio signals. Despite losing communication with the satellite in November 2022, ICON had already gathered valuable data on airglow, the relationship between the atmosphere's ions and Earth's magnetic field lines, and the first concrete observation to confirm Earth's ionospheric dynamo.

articles.title: After a day off, bear seen in Missouri. Is this the same one from southern Illinois?
articles.description: Missouri has an established bear population while Illinois does not.
articles.content:
After a day off, bear seen in Missouri. Is this the same one from southern Illinois?

A black bear was seen Wednesday afternoon in southern Missouri about 30 miles from a similar sighting in southern ... [1884 symbols]
articles.summary: A black bear was seen in southern Missouri, about 30 miles from a similar sighting in southern Illinois. The sighting raises questions about whether the bear from southern Illinois had made its way to Missouri by swimming across the Mississippi River. There have been numerous black bear sightings in southern southern Illinois this month, but none for about 48 hours. Missouri has an established population of black bears, with an estimated 900 in the state. A bear hunting season was established in 2021 and this year's season is set for Oct. 21-30.

articles.title: YouTube video of moose kill nets fines and hunting ban for Sask. brothers
articles.description: It's no surprise that many conservation officers are outdoor enthusiasts who like to hunt or fish and watch videos of others doing the same.A Saskatchewan conservation officer (CO) wasn't looking for Wildlife Act violations when he clicked on a YouTube video of a bull moose hunt in the Hudson Bay area. But the officer noticed possible hunting infractions.The video set off a chain of events leading to physical evidence and a lengthy investigation resulting in a range of hunting violation charges
articles.content: A still image from a video uploaded to YouTube by David Ostapiw, who is holding up the antlers of a bull moose he shot on a hunting trip. David and his brother Steven pleaded guilty to a range of Sask... [4952 symbols]
articles.summary: Saskaskan brothers, David and Steven Ostapiw, have been fined $6,220 and banned from hunting for a year after a YouTube video of a moose hunt sparked an investigation into possible hunting violations. The video, which was uploaded to YouTube by David, was seen leading to physical evidence and a lengthy investigation. The brothers pleaded guilty to a range of offences including unlawfully hunting, possessing antlers without a seal attached, using another person's game seal, and providing false information to an officer. Ryan Reimer, inspector for the provincial Conservation Officer Service, said that social media sleuthing is becoming more frequent due to public tips and hunters' pride in their actions.

articles.title: Insiders claim Apple plans to launch foldable iPhone in next two years
articles.description: Apple has long been rumored to have plans for a clam-style device, but now a new report claims two different-sized prototypes are in the works, coded named 'V68'
articles.content:
Apple is developing its first-ever foldable iPhone — with insiders reporting that this unusual new device is currently on track to launch in less than two years.

The tech giant has long been rumored ... [3873 symbols]
articles.summary: Apple is reportedly developing its first-ever foldable iPhone, codenamed 'V68', which is expected to launch in less than two years. The tech giant has long been rumored to have plans for a clam-style smartphone, previously publishing numerus patents. However, a new report has now revealed that two different-sized prototypes are currently in the works, with suppliers in Asia in talks to produce components for these devices. The report attributes its intel to 'two people with direct knowledge of the matter' who said it typically takes 24 months for a new iPhone model to develop, but this could take longer than usual. The company's industrial design team wants true 'razor' thinness for the iPhone Flip, half as thick as today's iPhones. However there are still challenges facing the foldable phone, including preventing a persistent crease from forming in the middle of the phone's display after repeated use.

A professional surfer who appeared to have lost his leg in a great white shark attack caught a lucky break when his limb washed ashore and was put on ice.

Doctors hope they can reattach Kai McKenzie’... [1422 symbols]
articles.summary: Professional surfer Kai McKenzie, who appeared to have lost his leg in a great white shark attack, was saved when his limb washed ashore and was put on ice. Doctors are hoping to reattach it at the southeast Australian trauma center where McKenzie was taken after the attack. A GoFundMe set up to cover McKenzie's medical costs had raised over $122,000 by Wednesday evening. The incident occurred off the shores of New South Wales, where multiple sharks were encountered in the area. There has reportedly been a spike in great white activity in the region.

articles.title: UPDATE: NASA, Boeing to Stream Flight Test Mission Briefing on NASA+
articles.description: NASA and Boeing will host a news conference with mission leadership at 11:30 a.m. EDT Thursday, July 25, to provide the latest status of the agency's Boeing Crew Flight Test aboard the International Space Station. NASA previously planned an audio-only media teleconference to host the discussion.
articles.content: WASHINGTON, July 24, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- NASA and Boeing will host a news conference with mission leadership at 11:30 a.m. EDT Thursday, July 25, to provide the latest status of the agency's Boeing C... [2530 symbols]
articles.summary: NASA and Boeing are set to host a news conference on July 25 to provide the latest status of the agency's Boeing Crew Flight Test aboard the International Space Station. The news conference will be broadcast on NASA+, NASA Television, the NASA app, YouTube, and the agency website. U.S. and international media are required to register in person for the event. The mission is part of NASA's Commercial Crew Program and involves an end-to-end test of the Starliner system. Following a successful return to Earth, NASA will begin the process of certifying Starliner for rotational missions to the ISS.

articles.title: Huge California dam removal project ahead of schedule — with historic return of wildlife to follow
articles.description: Dam demolition on the Klamath River, along the California-Oregon border, could be completed late August, opening up hundreds of miles of waterway to salmon
articles.content: The dams are being removed in a bid to restore the Klamath’s natural flows and, in doing so, revive the region’s fish and wildlife, notably salmon. Considered sacred by tribes and fundamental to fishe... [3525 symbols]
articles.summary: The removal of dams in the Klamath, California, is ahead of schedule to restore the region's natural flows and revive the region’s fish and wildlife, particularly salmon. The dams have blocked access to hundreds of miles of waterways where salmon historically spawned, leading to an increase in salmon numbers by up to 80%. The project aims to remove these dams and open up new spawning habitat to increase chinook salmon by as much as 80% more. The removal of these dams could occur before large numbers of chinook began migrating up the river from the ocean this fall, allowing the fish to reclaim their old home. However, scientists predict that the historic habitat of salmon won't be fully repopulated for a decade or longer.

articles.title: Carvings of Tutankhamun's grandfather discovered deep in Nile River
articles.description: Archaeologists uncovered rock slabs depicting carvings of pharaohs that ruled during the 18th and 26th dynasties. The slabs also had hieroglyphic inscriptions that had been submerged in the Nile.
articles.content:
Ancient carvings featuring the faces of Tutankhamun's grandfather and other ancient Egyptian pharaohs have been rediscovered.

Archaeologists found the giant stone slabs at the bottom of the Nile Rive... [3012 symbols]

the General Administration for Sunken Archaeological Archaeology

articles.summary: Archaeologists have discovered ancient carvings of Egyptian pharaohs, including those of Tutankhamun's grandfather and King Thutmose IV. The ancient carps were found at the bottom of the Nile River while searching for artifacts lost in a flood in Aswan in the 1970s. The carvations, which were discovered in 1960, were lost during the construction of the Aswan High Dam. Researchers have been able to study the rock formations in the area for the first time and are creating 3D models using photogrammetry to create an accurate three-dimensional version. The Egyptian Ministry of Tourism did not provide a translation for the hieroglyphs or describe what the caravings looked like. The researchers hope these findings will help them understand the 18th dynasty's reigns.

articles.summary: NASA researchers have successfully tested laser communications in space by sending 4K video footage from an airplane to the International Space Station and back. The feat demonstrates that NASA could provide live coverage of a Moon landing during the Artemis missions and could pave the way for optical communications that could connect humans to Mars and beyond. The technology was used to send data using infrared light, which can transmit data 10 to 100 times faster than traditional radio waves. The data was sent via a terrestrial network to NASA’s New Mexico test facility, where scientists controlled the process of beaming data up to the agency’�s Laser Communications Relay Demonstration (LCRD) satellite 22,000 miles away. Although the Artemis mission has been delayed, the fourth one to return humans to the Moon is scheduled for 2028.

articles.title: Surprise Yellowstone geyser eruption highlights little known hazard at popular park
articles.description: A surprise eruption of steam in a Yellowstone National Park geyser basin that sent people scrambling for safety as basketball-sized rocks flew overhead has highlighted a little-known hazard that scientists hope to be able to predict someday.
articles.content: BILLINGS, Mont. (AP) — A of steam in a Yellowstone National Park geyser basin that sent people scrambling for safety as basketball-sized rocks flew overhead has highlighted a little-known hazard that ... [5684 symbols]
articles.summary: A surprise hydrothermal explosion in Yellowstone National Park geyser basin has highlighted a little-known hazard that scientists hope to predict someday. The explosion, which occurred without warning, left people scrambling for safety as rocks, steam, water and dirt flying into the air. The scientists are working to develop a monitoring system that measures seismic activity, deformations in Earth’s surface and low-frequency acoustic energy that could signal an eruption. The explosions are believed to result from clogged passageways in the natural plumbing network under Yellowstone, which could cause heated water to turn into steam and explode. The incident highlighted a less common and understood type of explosion that is less understood than the ones seen at Old Faithful.

articles.summary: NASA's most powerful X-ray space telescope, the Chandra X-rays Observatory, has been used to discover the invisible secrets of the universe for decades. The Einstein Observatory pioneered X-Ray astronomy in the late '70s, but the Chandra Observatory, which has been in space for 25 years, pioneered the field in the 1970s. The telescope has been instrumental in uncovering the universe's secrets using X-radiation techniques. Here are some of the most stunning images and discoveries of the invisible X-raz universe.
